III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to
Section requirements; staff qualifications
Description (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Law enforcement was contacted due to concerns expressed that a
staff was attempting to a look at a youth who was changing.
Investigation Interviews:
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed via phone on
8/30/24. CA reported he and Clinical Manager (CM) spoke with
Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C to understand what occurred from
their individual perspectives. All three youth reported Program
Manager (PM) came into Youth A’s room, without knocking, while
Youth A was in the middle of changing her clothes. CA reported
the youth approached their concerns as PM was disrespectful to
them and their privacy rather than accusing him of being a sexual
predator. CA reported PM did not violate any protocols as they
have no policies requiring staff to knock when completing room
checks. However, CA reported they could improve practice to
include a knock, then immediately open the door process to
mitigate this issue in the future.
Youth A was interviewed via phone on 9/5/24. Youth A reported
she was in her room getting changed and getting ready for school
the following day. Youth A reported it was her, Youth B, and Youth
C in the bedroom. Youth A reported while she was taking her
clothes off, PM “bust” in the room, stood in the doorway for about
a minute staring at her, and then left the room. Youth A reported
he didn’t say anything during the interaction. Youth A reported PM
came back for another room check, and PM got into a verbal
argument with Youth B. Youth A reported Youth B stated she was
going to call the police. Youth A reported normally staff knock
before entering the bedrooms when doing room checks, but this
time he didn’t. Youth A reported PM has never done anything like
this before, but he should be more careful considering he’s a male
staff working with female youth.
Attempts were made via phone and text to interview Youth B
on 9/5/24 and 9/27/24, but no return contact was received.
Youth B was no longer at the facility at the time the investigation
began.
2

Youth C was interviewed via phone on 9/5/24. Youth C
reported PM came in at midnight, and during his first round of
room checks, he entered her and Youth A’s room without
knocking. Youth C reported Youth A was changing at the time.
Youth C reported when PM opened the door, he slowly looked
over Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C, and then left. Youth C
reported after PM shut the door, Youth C reported she yelled he
needed to knock next time. Youth C reported they locked the
bedroom door after PM left. When PM came to do the next room
check, the door was locked, and PM told them they couldn’t lock
the door. Youth C reported they have previously been told they
could lock the doors while they’re changing, but for some reason
PM said it couldn’t happen anymore. Youth C reported PM told
them if they had a problem with what he was doing, they could
contact the authorities, so Youth C called the police to report him.
Youth C reported every other staff knocks when doing room
checks, and PM usually does too, but for some reason he didn’t
that night.
Clinical Manager (CM) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 9/3/24. CM reported all three youth met with her and
CA after the incident to process what happened. Youth A told
them she had her jeans and a sports bra on when PM opened the
door for a room check. Youth A reported when PM opened the
door, she felt PM was staring at her while she was in a state of
undress. CM reported Youth B confirmed she felt PM was staring,
but Youth C stated she didn’t notice him staring. CM reported
Youth A was mostly upset PM did not knock before entering the
room.
Program Manager (PM) was interviewed via phone on 9/5/24.
PM reported upon arriving on shift at midnight, he began
conducting room checks. PM reported bedroom doors are
supposed to be unlocked and cracked at night, but when he
arrived at Youth A’s door, it wasn’t cracked. PM reported he
opened the door to complete the check and Youth A was wearing
jeans and a sports bra. PM reported Youth B and Youth C were
also in the room, although Youth B wasn’t supposed to be
because it wasn’t her room. PM informed Youth B she shouldn’t
be in the room and asked her to leave. PM reported none of the
youth said anything to him when he opened the door. PM reported
he was only in the doorway for a few seconds before leaving. PM
reported when he completed the next room check, the door was
locked even though it shouldn’t have been. PM reported he
knocked on the door and no one answered, so he asked Staff 1 to
complete the room check and unlock the door because she was a
3

female staff, and he felt the youth locked the door intentionally to
keep him out. PM reported when Staff 1 opened the door, all three
youth stated PM looked at them inappropriately, which is why they
locked the door. PM told Staff 1 not to engage with them and told
them if they felt their rights had been violated, they needed to
follow the grievance process. PM reported instead of following the
grievance process, the youth decided to contact the police, who
came and spoke with them.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 9/27/24. Staff 1 reported
Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C were locking their bedroom doors
throughout the night, prior to PM coming in for his shift. Staff 1
reported she was in the office writing notes while PM was
completing room checks. Staff 1 reported on the second round of
room checks, PM came back to the office to get Staff 1 and let her
know Youth A’s bedroom door was locked. PM asked Staff 1 to
unlock the door and complete the room check because she was a
female staff. Staff 1 went to Youth A’s room, unlocked the door,
and entered the room without knocking. Staff 1 reported as soon
as she opened the door, Youth B said, “[PM] was looking at us”,
and then Youth B began cussing at her and calling her
inappropriate names. Staff 1 reported PM told her not to engage
with the youth, and PM was trying to diffuse the situation. Staff 1
reported Youth B said, “fine, if you’re not going to do anything,
then I’m going to call the police” and then said, “we’re going to
show him”. Staff 1 reported it was clearly Youth B’s intention to get
PM in trouble even though he didn’t do anything wrong. Staff 1
reported PM is a very professional man, and she has never had
any concerns with his performance or interactions with the youth.
Staff 1 reported staff can knock on the door before entering, but
it’s not a requirement for room checks. Staff 1 reported if she
knocks on the door, she doesn’t wait for a response before
entering the room.
VIDEO REVIEWED:
Video footage from 8/28/24 was viewed. The video shows PM
completing bedroom checks at 12:16 am. He opens two different
bedroom doors, stands at the doorway of each, closes the doors,
and walks away. The bedroom checks were approximately 3-5
seconds long. PM did not knock prior to opening each of the two
bedrooms.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Agency Response Strategy email dated 8/28/24 states PM
will be kept away from youth while investigation is
underway.
4

• Incident Report dated 8/28/24 completed by PM is
consistent with PM’s interview.
• Royal Oak Police Department report #240031796 dated
8/28/24 was consistent with interviews conducted.
• Resident Supervision Policy (rev. 7/10/24) outlines staff
requirements for completing bed checks. It does not note
staff are required to knock on bedroom doors prior to
entering rooms.
• Employee Handbook states the agency practices a zero-
tolerance policy for intentional illegal and/or unethical
behavior. It notes youth have the right to be treated with
consideration and respect, with due recognition of personal
dignity, individuality, and the need of privacy.
• Staff, Volunteer & Intern Handbook provides information on
the process for overnight room check procedures for youth.
It does not note staff are required to knock on bedroom
doors prior to entering rooms.
• Basic Center Resident Handbook states bedroom doors
are to remain partially open throughout the night, youth are
not allowed in each other’s rooms, and bed checks will be
conducted every 15 minutes or less throughout the night.
• A Step Forward Resident Handbook states bedroom
checks will be made in variable increments not to exceed
15 minutes, youth are not allowed in each other’s rooms,
and the bedroom doors are not allowed to be locked while
youth are occupying the room.
• Program Manager (PM) has one disciplinary action and one
performance improvement plan in his employee file,
unrelated to this investigation. PM’s training log did not note
when he was trained on room check or supervision policies.
However, PM sent a message on 7/15/24 reminding staff
about the room check policy and provided them the Staff,
Volunteer & Intern Handbook (specifically noting pages 18-
19) for review.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per interviews, video
footage reviewed, and documents reviewed, Program Manager
performed the duties of his position appropriately.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
